conclusion: The relationship between pressure, volume, and temperature for an ideal gas is given by the ideal-gas equation pV = nRT.
At state A, the pressure is pA = p0, volume is VA = V0, and temperature is TA = T0.
Substitute state A values into the ideal-gas equation to get p0 V0 = nR T0.
The line segment AB is horizontal in the V–T diagram, indicating constant pressure along A → B.
At state B, the pressure remains pB = p0.
Using the ideal-gas equation at state B gives p0 VB = nR TB.
Substitute VB = 2V0 into the equation for state B to get p0 (2V0) = nR TB and combine with the equation for state A to find TB = 2T0.
The straight-line segment B → C extends through the origin, indicating B, C, and O are collinear in the V–T plane.
For a straight line through the origin, the ratio V/T is constant, so V/T = constant on OB and OC.
At state B, VB / TB = 2V0 / (2T0) = V0 / T0.
Every point C on the line satisfies VC / TC = V0 / T0.
From the graph, VC = V0 as the dashed horizontal line from V0 meets the line at C.
Substitute VC = V0 into the equation for point C to find V0 / TC = V0 / T0, leading to TC = T0.
The temperature at state C is determined to be TC = T0.
